title: Keynsham Walks

images.title: Phil Williams / CC BY-SA (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)
images.caption: War memorial at Upton Cheney. A view looking to the southeast from Wick Lane towards the war memorial shelter on Brewery Hill. The inscription records that " Upton Cheney, Beach and Golden Valley sent 55 men to the Great War of whom 7 gave their lives."

images.title: Rick Crowley / Milward House, Keynsham
images.caption: Milward House, Keynsham Situated opposite Station Rd, and is now used by Keynsham and District Community Learning Difficulties Team. A old feature is the triangular shaped bay window on the right. It once had leaded diamond shaped windows.

images.title: Rick Crowley / Old Manor House, Keynsham
images.caption: Old Manor House, Keynsham. The Old Manor House is said to be one of the oldest inhabited buildings in England. The front is early 17th century, but other parts prove that it is much older. It is now a restaurant.

description: Keynsham is a Somerset market town located a few miles south east of Bristol. The town can be reached on foot from Bristol by following a riverside path from the city centre. There's also a train station if you prefer to come by public transport. It's about a 10 minute ride from Bristol Temple Meads. The attractive town is a nice place for a walk with lush countryside, river walks and a popular country park. This walk from the town visits the Avon Valley Country Park and the village of Upton Cheyney to the north east of the town. The walk starts at the train station at the northern edge of the town. From here you can pick up the River Avon Trail and follow the waymarked footpath east along the river to the associated country park. Cross to the other side on the footbridge and you can explore the park which includes country walks, a boating lake, play areas for children, a small petting zoo and a miniature railway. After exploring the park you return to the river and continue east to visit Upton Cheyney. From the village you can pick up the Monarch's Way and follow the waymarked trail west through the countryside, to the train station.
